name: 文學與藝術
description:
The purpose of this course is to provide students with an introductory history of western art and its literary reception. Each week we will be looking at a different cluster of visual artworks and discussing it with reference to (1) its own cultural context and (2) a short literary text written in response or as a complement to it. 

The course will, in the main, follow the chronology of the visual artworks that we will be considering. This means we will move from medieval to modern/contemporary periods of artistic production. The literary texts we will be looking at are mostly poems from the twentieth century. Students on this course will always be encouraged to try out their own interpretations of works of visual art and literary texts alike.
goals: To provide students with an introductory history of western art and its literary reception
syllabus:
Email: aaron.c.deveson@gmail.com

**Schedule (may be affected by Taiwanese holidays)**

1\. Introduction

2\. Pieter Brueghel, _Landscape with the Fall of Icarus_ (c. 1558); W.H. Auden, “In the Musée des Beaux Arts”

3\. Anonymous Flemish artist, _Medusa’s Head_ (c. 1600); Percy Bysshe Shelley, “On the Medusa of Leonardo Da Vinci in the Florentine Gallery”

4\. Contd. from previous week (with new presentations)

5\. Pieter De Hooch, _The Courtyard of a House in Delft_ (1658-60); Derek Mahon, “Courtyards in Delft”

6\. William Blake, “London” (1794)

7\. Revision

8\. Midterm

10\. Jean-August Dominique Ingres, _Roger and Angelica_ (_Ruggiero Delivering Angelica_) (1839); Dante Gabriel Rossetti, various works

11\. Vincent Van Gogh, _Starry Night_ (1889); Anne Sexton, “The Starry Night”

12\. Edvard Munch, _Girls on a Bridge_ (1901); Derek Mahon, “Girls on the Bridge”

13\. Pablo Picasso, _Guernica_ (1937) and other works; R.S. Thomas, “Guernica”

14\. Various works of art; Frank O’Hara, “Having a Coke with You”

15\. Willy Ronis, various photographic works; David Constantine, “Nude”

16\. Revision

17\. Final

grading.note:
Presentation (20%). Each student will do one presentation, which should last no longer than 4 mins. The presentation will provide background material on the artist/artistic period covered in the session. The presentation must include at least three images. 
Midterm and final (40% each). In each exam students will compare and contrast two or more poems from the course. These essays will explain how these poems’ dealings with the world of visual art.    Plagiarism will not be tolerated: document every source you make use of in your work.
